bestBHT.bht: In that moment, Jesus, the well-known prophet from Nazareth and the awaited Messiah, was passing by. The variations in English tenses used can be attributed to the use of present middle indicative in indirect discourse, as seen in Matthew 20:30. This passing of Jesus caused quite a stir among the people who had heard so much about him and his teachings. The noise and clamor ensued as Jesus, known for his ability to heal diseases and cast out demons, was making his way through.

Archibald T. Robertson: No reason for differences of English tenses in the two passages (was passing by, passeth by).
Present middle indicative retained in indirect discourse as παραγε is in Matthew 20:30.
Passeth by (παρερχετα). Present middle indicative retained in indirect discourse.
John Gill: Jesus, the prophet of Nazareth, so much talked of, and said to be the Messiah, who was become so famous for his doctrines and miracles."
Healing diseases, and dispossessing devils, was just 'then' passing by."
This occasioned the noise and clamour.

bhtAttempts.bht: At that moment, Jesus, the renowned prophet of Nazareth and the proclaimed Messiah, was passing by. There was no reason for differences in the English tenses used in various translations of the passage, as it was merely indicating the act of Jesus passing by. This caused a great commotion among the people, as Jesus had gained quite a reputation for his teachings and miracles. The present middle indicative, παρερχετα, used in indirect discourse, emphasizes Jesus ongoing action of passing by in the midst of all the noise and clamor.

In that moment, Jesus, the well-known prophet from Nazareth and the awaited Messiah, was passing by. The variations in English tenses used can be attributed to the use of present middle indicative in indirect discourse, as seen in Matthew 20:30. This passing of Jesus caused quite a stir among the people who had heard so much about him and his teachings. The noise and clamor ensued as Jesus, known for his ability to heal diseases and cast out demons, was making his way through.

Amidst the commotion, Jesus, the renowned prophet from Nazareth and the anticipated Messiah, was passing by. The English tenses used in different translations can be attributed to the present middle indicative in indirect discourse, as noted in Matthew 20:30. The presence of Jesus, known for his miraculous healings and power over demons, caused a stir among the people. The passage emphasizes the ongoing action of Jesus passing by, setting the stage for the noise and clamor surrounding this momentous event.

At that moment, Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth, who had gained fame for his teachings and miracles, was passing by. The variations in English tenses used reflect the ongoing action of Jesus passing by, as seen in Matthew 20:30. The people were stirred up by this occasion, causing a great commotion and clamor. His presence and the reports of his extraordinary abilities created a buzz around Jesus as he continued on his way.

In that moment, Jesus, the renowned prophet of Nazareth and the acclaimed Messiah, was passing by. The people were stirred up by this occasion, causing a great commotion and clamor. They had heard much about Jesus, who was famous for his teachings and miracles. The use of different English tenses, specifically the present middle indicative in indirect discourse, simply indicated the ongoing action of Jesus passing by. This emphasized the significance of his presence and the buzz it generated among the people.
